content.description: Stiff 5.8 crimping and edging on flexy Rye-krisp flakes.   Calling this a 'sport' route isn't probably fair, though; more like 'bolt-protected face/friction'.  It has the feel of having been bolted on lead.
content.protection: 6 bolts to the 2-bolt rap anchor shared with Paleface.
content.location: Starts up a small rib near the right-center of the face, right of all the brown and gray water streaks.   Rap with 2 ropes.

content.description: Right-most climb on Paleface Slab. Step right to the pod, clip the first bolt and begin your quest up thin edges, following the well spaced bolt line.  You'll likely be more excited than usual to clip the homemade aluminum hanger.  2x60m ropes to rappel, or walk-off, or lug an 80m up and you can TR this.Great moderate for the aspiring 5.11 slab leader.
content.location: Starts on top of a HUGE boulder that leans against the slab.

climbs.name: Lord of the Flies
climbs.fa: Matt Juaire, Mike Herholz, Jeff Ladderud

content.description: 1st pitch: right crack of any established routes through a chimney roof area to a tree belay with an abundance of flies and lizards. 2nd pitch: short climb over a crack in a rock. 3rd pitch: very wide layback with a seated belay. Traverse to the left to start 4th pitch: up low angle pitch to complete the climb. Hike off the left (south) ravine to get back to the wash and re-approach to retrieve any packs.
content.location: Right-most crack/chimney, facing into the wash.

content.description: Great, well-protected slab and thin face climbing on a distinctive brown water streak.
content.protection: Bolted. Fixed anchors. Best to rap the route (2 ropes)
content.location: The route ascends the obvious brown water streak in the middle of the rock.

content.description: A beautiful, well-protected, moderate climb on a distinctive water streak. Crux is getting to the 1st bolt.
content.protection: Bolted. Fixed anchors. Best to rap the route (2 ropes)
content.location: The route ascends the obvious bluish-gray water streak on the left side of the rock.

content.description: Paleface Slab is a clean face with a southerly aspect and relatively easy access in the Western Stronghold.  Both Kerry's (1997) and Abbott's (2006) guidebooks list three routes. Two of these can be recognized by their SMC hangers.    At least two new additional tightly-bolted lines with big gray hangers have recently been installed.  (Plus, there are a number of oddly placed old bolts in the waterstreak area where Feast of Friends is purported to go; I'm not sure what they belong to; the top bolt is a buttonhead with a Leeper hanger, so I'm not gonna try that one).
